subject: Re: [junit] Applicability - Where not to Use JUnit
msgSnippet: Sateesh, You can use DBUnit with JUnit and in-memory database (i.e.HSQLDB) to test your functionality of fetching, inserting, updating data in the database
messageBody:
Sateesh,
You can use DBUnit with JUnit and in-memory database (i.e.HSQLDB) to test
your functionality of fetching, inserting, updating data in the database
(HSQLDB) instead of your original database. So while testing your
functionality, dummy data will not be inserted into your original
database.

Regards..
Kamlesh Kumar
S/W Engineer, Pune






"Kamal" <kamal2222ahmed@...>
Sent by: junit@yahoogroups.com
03/26/2008 03:28 PM
Please respond to
junit@yahoogroups.com


To
<junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc

Subject
Re: [junit] Applicability - Where not to Use JUnit









Sateesh,

try a combination of XQuery and Xpath, using JUnit as an assert structure,
and you have yourself a frame work to test your application.

-Kamal.
----- Original Message -----
From: Sateesh
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 26, 2008 3:36 AM
Subject: [junit] Applicability - Where not to Use JUnit

Hi,
In our application, we planned to use JUnit. but our application is
like fetching, inserting, updating data in the databases. there is no
domain bussiness logics involved. that is there will be no
calculations etc., We feel that for our application testing could be
done manually. Even if we try with JUnit, the time taken for test case
preparation is almost equal to the time taken to implement the
functionality. Pls instruct me.

with regards,
Sateesh
